description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. This is a medical emergency that requires immediate attention.}, {diagnosis: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
description: Often called a \mini-stroke,\ a TIA is caused by a temporary clot. TIAs dont have lasting effects but are a serious warning sign of a future stroke.}, {diagnosis: Brain tumor

description: Aphasia, weakness, and phonophobia can be symptoms of a brain tumor, especially if the tumor is located in areas of the brain responsible for language, movement, or sensory processing.}, {diagnosis: Migraine with aura

description: While not as common as other symptoms, aphasia and weakness can occur during the aura phase of a migraine. Phonophobia is a common symptom of migraine.}, {diagnosis: Multiple sclerosis (MS)
description: MS affects the central nervous system and can cause a wide range of neurological symptoms, including aphasia, weakness, and sensitivity to sound.}, {diagnosis: Bells palsy
description: Bells palsy typically causes facial weakness but can also lead to sound sensitivity and, less commonly, difficulty speaking.}, {diagnosis: Guillain-Barré syndrome
description: This rare autoimmune disorder affects the peripheral nervous system and can cause weakness, sensory changes, and in some cases, difficulty speaking.}, {diagnosis: Meningitis

description: Meningitis is an inflammation of the membranes that surround the brain and spinal cord. It can cause a range of neurological symptoms, including aphasia, weakness, and sensitivity to sound.}, {diagnosis: Encephalitis

description: Encephalitis is an inflammation of the brain itself and can cause similar symptoms to meningitis, including aphasia, weakness, and phonophobia.}, {diagnosis: Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD)

description: While primarily a mental health condition, PTSD can manifest physically with symptoms like phonophobia, fatigue (which can be perceived as weakness), and difficulty concentrating or finding words (which can resemble aphasia).}
